# Draft:Hrishikesh Pawar

Hrishikesh Pawar
Hrishikesh Pawar (born 1983) is an Indian Kathak and contemporary dancer, choreographer and teacher based in Pune, Maharashtra. He is the founder and artistic director of the Hrishikesh Centre of Contemporary Dance and the curator/director of the Prayatna Film & Dance Festival in Pune. Pawar is known for community-facing projects, particularly an ongoing Dance for Parkinson’s program that provides free dance classes for people living with Parkinson’s disease, and for his international residencies and collaborations, including the Junge Akademie / Berlin Fellowship (Akademie der Kuenste).
ADK Hrishikesh Pawar Hrishikesh Pawar
Early life and training
Pawar was born in Pune in 1983. He trained in Kathak under Pandit Rohini Bhate and later continued advanced studies in contemporary dance, including time as a guest student at the Palucca Hochschule für Tanz (Dresden). He holds a Masters (or diploma) in dance teaching from Palucca (as stated in institutional profiles). He presently is grooming himself under Guru Neelima Adhye.
Career
From the 2000s Pawar has worked as a performer, choreographer and teacher in Pune and beyond. He established the Hrishikesh Centre of Contemporary Dance (often cited as Hrishikesh’s Centre of Contemporary Dance) which runs regular classes, workshops and community projects. He also founded and curates the Prayatna Film & Dance Festival, an annual festival in Pune that presents contemporary and traditional dance alongside film screenings and workshops; the festival has run for multiple editions and collaborated with cultural institutions such as the Alliance Française and the Max Mueller Bhavan.
Pawar has presented choreography and workshops in India and internationally, and has been profiled in national and international press outlets that have documented his projects and community work.
Dance for Parkinson’s / community work
Since 2009 Pawar has led a sustained Dance for Parkinson’s program at his Centre in Pune, providing free or low-cost classes designed to improve balance, mobility and well-being for older adults living with Parkinson’s disease. This program has been covered by national and international outlets, including The National, The Better India and press items in Indian newspapers, which note the program’s longevity and impact on participants’ quality of life. The program has also been included in international conversations about dance and health.
Recognition and residencies
In 2024 Pawar was selected for the Junge Akademie / Berlin Fellowship in the Performing Arts at the Akademie der Kuenste (Berlin), an artist residency/fellowship program run by the Akademie that supports international artists across disciplines. The Akademie describes Pawar as “among the important voices of Indian contemporary dance.” This institutional fellowship is a notable independent credential.
Other press coverage and festival listings (Times of India, Pune Mirror, DNA India, Culture Crossroads, The Better India and regional press) document Pawar’s work as a teacher, choreographer and curator.
culture crossroads.
Selected projects and festivals
Hrishikesh Centre of Contemporary Dance — founder and Artistic Director; runs classes, workshops and community programs(including Parkinson’s classes).
Prayatna Film & Dance Festival — founder/curator; festival editions documented from at least the 2010s through 2025, with collaborations involving the Alliance Française and Max Mueller Bhavan (Goethe Institute).
International presentations and residencies — academic/curatorial engagements such as lectures and shows in European institutions and the 2024 Berlin Fellowship.
Media and public presence
Pawar has been the subject of feature pieces (The Better India, The National), local newspaper interviews (Pune Mirror, Times of India), event listings, and arts-sector profiles (Arts Front). He maintains an official website and active social media profiles (Instagram, Facebook, LinkedIn) that document his classes, festival activity and public program. These self-published sources are useful for non-controversial factual details (dates of upcoming events, class schedules) but should not be used as the sole source for claims about notability.
